user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_rmfs:
```c
int32 OS_rmfs(const char *devname)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(devname);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, devname, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * NOTE: It is likely that if the file system is mounted,
         * this call to stop the volume will fail.
         *
         * It would be prudent to first check the flags to ensure that
         * the filesystem is unmounted first, but this would break
         * compatibility with the existing unit tests.
         */
        return_code = OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(&token);

        /* Free the entry in the master table  */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only function parameter is devname, so the function declaration is included for context. The two calls that use devname (the OS_CHECK_PATHNAME macro and the OS_ObjectIdGetByName call) are flagged because a macro expansion or the called routine could (illegally) assign to or otherwise modify the parameter pointer itself. All other lines in the function do not reference or assign to the parameter devname: assignments to return_code, the use and modification of token via &token, the calls OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(&token) and OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(...,&token), and the comments cannot change the function parameter pointer, so they do not need investigation for Rule 17.8.
